awd_titl_txt: The Ninth International GEOS-Chem Meeting (IGC9); Cambridge, Massachusetts; May 6-9, 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
This project support student and early career travel to the 9th International GEOS-Chem Meeting (IGC9). The GEOS-Chem Meeting is held at Harvard every two years and is a major event for the global atmospheric chemistry modeling community, with about 200 attendees and a very broad range of topics.  GEOS-Chem is an open-source global 3-D model of atmospheric composition used actively by over 150 research groups around the world, including 52 in the US.  This meeting will bring together experts to exchange information that will inform and stimulate fundamental research in modeling of atmospheric composition with links to climate dynamics, biogeochemistry, and air quality.  

Applications of GEOS-Chem span a very wide range of atmospheric composition problems including oxidants, aerosols, carbon gases, stratospheric chemistry, mercury, persistent organic pollutants, and others. GEOS-Chem links with Earth System Models for studies of chemistry-climate-ecosystem interactions, with meteorological data systems for chemical data assimilation, with regional models for air quality applications, and with assessment models for policy applications.  The GEOS-Chem model is centrally managed at Harvard with guidance from a Steering Committee including 17 US university professors.  A GEOS-Chem Support Team based at Harvard, University of Colorado, and Dalhousie University is responsible for model development, benchmarking, documentation, communication, and education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported the organization of the 9th International GEOS-Chem Meeting (IGC9) held at Harvard on May 6-9, 2019. GEOS-Chem is an open-source global three-dimensional model of atmospheric composition that describes how the concentrations of air pollutants and greenhouse gases are related to emissions, transport, atmospheric chemistry, and deposition. It serves to interpret atmospheric observations as a test of our understanding and to make future projections on the basis of various scenarios.

GEOS-Chem is used by over 200 research groups around the world including about 50 groups at US universities. GEOS-Chem users gather every two years at IGC meetings. These are major events for the atmospheric chemistry research community, with about 200 attendees and a very broad range of topics. Oral presentations by early-career scientists and graduate students are prioritized, providing for many a first opportunity to present their work in front of a large international audience.

Funds from this grant were disbursed by the PI to US students and early-career scientists as individual travel allocations of $1,000. They were also used to invite three prominent experimental atmospheric chemists to deliver keynote presentations. 

IGC9 was by all accounts a huge success, with over 230 participants. A listing of the agenda with links to the presentations can be found here: http://acmg.seas.harvard.edu/geos/meetings/2019/index.html

Intellectual merit: Exchange of information at IGC9 informed and stimulated fundamental research in modeling of atmospheric composition with links to climate dynamics, biogeochemistry, and air quality. Most of the meeting time was dedicated to research presentations, both oral and through poster sessions.

Broader impacts:  The developing partnership of the GEOS-Chem community with the NSF-funded National Center for Atmospheric Research was a major theme of the meeting. IGC9 gave graduate students and early-career scientists an opportunity to showcase their research through oral presentations. Social events and model clinics promoted further engagement. IGC9 is a particularly valuable meeting for graduate students and postdocs contemplating academic careers because of the large attendance from US university groups and the collegiality of the GEOS-Chem community.
